awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of a Confocal Microscope for Multi-disciplinary Research
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Santa Clara University to acquire a cutting-edge confocal microscope. Students and faculty performing research in anthropology, biology, bioengineering, and chemistry will use this confocal microscope. This microscope allows researchers to make accurate and precise measurements in three dimensions over time. This microscope enables faculty and students to collect critical scientific data that will help address core questions in molecular and developmental biology of both plants and animals. This microscope will also be used to study the interaction of certain widespread chemicals with common protein structures. The three dimensional shape of fossilized plant cells will be captured on this microscope, and that information will be used to inform models of past environments and plant evolution. Additionally this microscope will be used to study the chemistry of specific emulsions, and to help develop fluorescent proteins switches that will aid scientists in multiple fields. Overall, a broad group of university faculty members and mentored student researchers will use this microscope to study key questions in multiple areas of biology and chemistry. 

		Santa Clara University is a primarily undergraduate university with student learning at its central focus. The introduction of a confocal microscope to campus will greatly enhance the opportunities for students to engage in scientific inquiry, while producing useful data. SCU science graduates often go on to medical school, graduate school, and the biotech industry. The success of SCU students is attributed to the hands-on experiences they receive in the laboratory and classroom. Students will be educated to use the confocal microscope in multiple faculty research labs and in several classes. The training they receive in quantitative and fluorescence microscopy will prepare them well for careers in diverse STEM fields. The microscope will be used in an annual outreach event to attract first-generation college students to the SCU science departments. This microscope will be used to address important scientific hypothesis and to train a diverse set of students. Exposure to this microscope will leave a positive impact on students, by increasing their scientific literacy and enabling them to pursue careers in STEM fields.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

This proposal was an application for funds to purchase a Leica SP8 confocal microscope for Santa Clara University (SCU), a primarily undergraduate institution with strong internal support for scholarship. The intended primary users are accomplished scholars who are dedicated to providing meaningful research experiences to the diverse student body at SCU. These researchers span multiple scientific disciplines, including cell and developmental biology, bioengineering, chemistry, and physical anthropology. Before this confocal microscope was acquired, the primary users were required to utilize off-campus confocal microscopes that were becoming increasingly back-logged (and expensive). The presence of this confocal microscope on the SCU campus has impacted research on microtubule bundling in plants, muscle cell differentiation in mammalian cells, and cell fusion and cell migration in nematodes:

1.     Co-Principal Investigator Dr Jessica Lucas used this confocal microscope to perform experiments to determine the role of microtubule bundles and associated proteins in microtubule organization and function in the model plant, Arabidopsis thaliana. The time-gated photomultiplier tubes and tunable laser were very helpful for this work because they allowed chlorophyll and other plant intrinsic autofluorescences to be excluded from detection. Specifically, Dr. Lucas used this scope to determine the localization of microtubule-associated proteins relative to each other and to microtubules. She also used the confocal to explore the reorganization of microtubules upon reentry into interphase after cell division. Finally, the confocal was used to build fluorescent protein reporter strains that will allow her to test the hypothesis that gas exchange is regulated by map65 and kinesin proteins via microtuble array organization.

2.     Dr. Grainger used this confocal microscope to visualize cells in tissue culture. He studies the effects of hypoxia and growth substrate on the differentiation of striated muscle cells from mesenchyme stem cells derived from adult muscle stem cells. Growing the cells on stiff plastic tissue culture dishes in oxygen environments that contain less than 1% oxygen triggers the stabilization of the HIF transcription factors and prevents the cells from differentiating. Under normal atmospheric oxygen conditions, the c2c12 cells grow and differentiate better than on plastic, stiff substrates.  To his surprise, he found that if he cultured the stem cells in 0.05% oxygen not only do the stem cells survive, but they proliferate and differentiate just like control cells grown in atmospheric oxygen.  Thus, changing the mechanical properties of the substrate the cells are grown on must trigger the cell division and cell survival pathways, along with the activation of muscle differentiation program even in the absence of oxygen. 

3.     Co-Principal Investigator Dr. Miller originally planned to use this confocal microscope to study morphogenesis in the C. elegans vulva using a GFP reporter construct that allows visualization of adherens junctions in epithelial sheets. Although it turned out that this particular confocal scope could not image fast enough to generate a 3D stack of ~200 images in an immobilized living worm, the acquisition of this confocal scope and initial training on it did kindle interest in this project, resulting in a sabbatical in Zurich using a spinning disc confocal. Those experiments revealed exciting results that certain phosphorylation-defective mutants in C. elegans have defects in both cell migration and cell fusion during vulval morphogenesis.

Broader Impacts:

Santa Clara University is a primarily undergraduate university that makes student learning its central focus. The University Mission Statement stipulates that student learning take place in an "educational environment that integrates rigorous inquiry and scholarship, creative imagination, reflective engagement with society and a commitment to fashioning a more humane and just world." The teacher-scholars at SCU are dedicated to providing undergraduates meaningful research experiences, both in the classroom and in our research labs to prepare them for graduate school and science careers. A specialized upper division course in microscopy was developed by Dr. Lucas, which included a module on confocal microscopy. The confocal microscope was also used to generate images from student projects in our undergraduate upper division "Cell Biology" and our "Embryology and Mechanical Signaling in Cells" classes under Dr. Grainger's supervision, and several SCU undergraduates were trained to use the confocal scope as part of their independent research projects.

 In Fall 2021, this confocal microscope was relocated to the third floor of our brand new Sobrato Campus for Discovery and Innovation -- the new home for the Sciences, Engineering, and Mathematics at Santa Clara University. This building is designed to support collaboration across traditional STEM disciplines and features state-of-the-art laboratory facilities where undergraduate and engineering graduate students can discover, learn, experiment, and innovate. The third floor houses parts of biology, chemistry, environmental sciences, neuroscience, and bioengineering. This instrument will increase interdisciplinary interactions and create synergistic collaborations among this diverse group of scholars.
